results.adx_keywords: Reading and Writing Skills (Education);Illiteracy;Dyslexia;Education (K-12);Teachers and School Employees;Content Type: Personal Profile;Calkins, Lucy;Teachers College of Columbia University
results.title: In the Fight Over How to Teach Reading, This Guru Makes a Major Retreat
results.abstract: Lucy Calkins, a leading literacy expert, has rewritten her curriculum to include a fuller embrace of phonics and the science of reading. Critics may not be appeased.

media.caption: Lucy Calkins, an education professor, created a popular curriculum called “Units of Study,” built on a vision of children as natural readers and writers.
media.copyright: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Slavery (Historical);Colonization;Coffee;Economic Conditions and Trends;Poverty;Politics and Government;Reparations;International Relations;Haiti;France
results.byline: By Catherine Porter, Constant Méheut, Matt Apuzzo and Selam Gebrekidan
results.title: The Root of Haiti’s Misery: Reparations to Enslavers
results.abstract: In 1791, enslaved Haitians ousted the French and founded a nation. But France made generations of Haitians pay for their freedom. How much it cost them was a mystery, until now.

media.caption: An illustration depicting plantations burning in 1791, during the Haitian Revolution.
media.copyright: Universal Images Group, via Getty Images

results.byline: By Talya Minsberg and Alexander Aguiar
results.title: These 90-Year-Old Runners Have Some Advice for You
results.abstract: Runners at the National Senior Games in Miramar, Fla., competed in events ranging from the 50 meters to 1,500 meters. Their secret? “You’ve got to keep moving.”

results.title: The Rules for Hybrid Work Were Always Made Up
results.abstract: As more and more workplaces pause or end the expectation of three days a week in the office, a large-scale return may never be on the horizon.

results.abstract: The onetime ‘manager of the century’ paved the way for C.E.O.s to moonlight as internet trolls.

results.title: A Daily Aspirin Regimen May Hurt More Than Help, Experts Warn
results.abstract: Millions of Americans take aspirin to prevent a first heart attack or stroke. Now, doctors are advising against it — especially for people over 70.
org_facet: Journal of the American Medical Assn
United States Preventive Services Task Force

media.caption: A panel of experts reviewing data on a daily aspirin regimen to prevent heart attacks found that the net benefit for most Americans is very small and that the practice can carry real risks.

results.adx_keywords: Cancer;Emotions;Empathy;Anxiety and Stress
results.title: People Say, ‘Be Positive’ When You Have Cancer. I Prefer to Complain With Friends.
results.abstract: Mutual complaint can be stabilizing.

results.title: The Russian Orthodox Leader at the Core of Putin’s Ambitions
results.abstract: Patriarch Kirill I has provided spiritual cover for the invasion of Ukraine, reaping vast resources for his church in return. Now, in an extraordinary step, the E.U. is threatening him with sanctions.

results.title: Lifting Weights? Your Fat Cells Would Like to Have a Word.
results.abstract: A cellular chat after your workout may explain in part why weight training burns fat.

results.title: ‘I Want to Reset My Brain’: Female Veterans Turn to Psychedelic Therapy
results.abstract: Traumatized by war and sexual assaults, some U.S. veterans and veterans’ spouses are seeking help in a Mexican clinic that treats depression and addiction with potent hallucinogens like toad poison.

results.abstract: The former chief foreign affairs correspondent is now a popular guest on podcasts hosted by vaccine skeptics and deniers of the 2020 election.

results.abstract: More than 1,000 terra-cotta sculptures — of firefighters, mermaids, steelworkers — adorn the walls of Parkchester in the Bronx. Is there a plan to protect them?

results.title: Stocks Have Been Falling. I’m Still Buying Steadily.
results.abstract: Is this is a good time to buy stocks, readers ask? Yes, our columnist says, but only if you can handle further losses and don’t try to outsmart the market.

results.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Shane Goldmacher
results.title: Perdue Had Trump. In Georgia, Kemp Had Everything Else.
results.abstract: David Perdue challenged Gov. Brian Kemp because of Donald Trump’s fury over his 2020 loss. Thoroughly outflanked and failing to gain traction, he is now staring down defeat.

media.caption: Former Senator David Perdue at a “Bikers for Trump” rally on May 20 in Plainville, Ga. Recruited by the former president, Mr. Perdue is widely expected to lose Tuesday’s Republican primary for governor.
